articles.title: First Steps as a New Carer
articles.summary: Essential guidance for those who have just taken on a caring role for an elderly loved one.
articles.content:
First Steps as a New Carer

Taking on the role of caring for an elderly person can be overwhelming, especially if it happens suddenly due to a health crisis. This guide will help you navigate your new responsibilities.

Getting Recognized as a Carer

Register with your GP as a carer and request a carer's assessment from your local council. This assessment will identify what support you need, regardless of your income.

Understanding the Person's Needs

Speak with healthcare professionals to understand the medical needs of the person you're caring for. Ask about their condition, medications, potential side effects, and warning signs to watch for.

Setting Up a Routine

Establish a consistent daily routine that works for both of you. Include time for medications, meals, exercise, social activities, and rest periods.

Essential Equipment and Adaptations

Consider what practical equipment might be needed, such as mobility aids, bathroom adaptations, or special bedding. An occupational therapist can assess home needs.

Emergency Planning

Create an emergency plan with contact information for healthcare providers, medication details, and alternative care arrangements.

Looking After Yourself

Remember that your wellbeing matters too. Identify sources of support for yourself, join a local carers group, and schedule regular breaks.
articles.author: Carol Johnson, Carers UK Advisor

articles.title: Understanding Carers Allowance
articles.summary: A comprehensive guide to claiming Carer's Allowance in the UK, including eligibility, application process, and how it affects other benefits.
articles.content:
Understanding Carer's Allowance

Carer's Allowance is the main welfare benefit available to carers in the UK. This guide explains everything you need to know about claiming this important financial support.

What is Carer's Allowance?

Carer's Allowance is a payment of £76.75 per week (as of April 2023) for people who spend at least 35 hours a week caring for someone who receives certain disability benefits.

Eligibility Requirements

To qualify for Carer's Allowance, you must:

  • Spend at least 35 hours a week caring for someone
  • Care for someone who receives certain disability benefits (such as Attendance Allowance or PIP daily living component)
  • Be 16 or over
  • Not be in full-time education
  • Not earn more than £139 per week (after deductions)
  • Meet UK residency requirements

How to Apply

You can apply online at gov.uk/carers-allowance, by phone (0800 731 0297), or by post using a claim form. You'll need details about yourself, the person you care for, and other benefits either of you receive.

Effect on Other Benefits

Carer's Allowance can affect other benefits you or the person you care for receives. It counts as taxable income and may affect means-tested benefits like Universal Credit. If the person you care for receives a severe disability premium, they may lose this if you claim Carer's Allowance.

Underlying Entitlement

Even if you can't receive Carer's Allowance payments (perhaps because you receive another benefit that 'overlaps' with it), you may have an 'underlying entitlement' that can increase other means-tested benefits you receive.

Regular Reviews

Your entitlement will be reviewed periodically, and you must report any changes in your circumstances promptly to avoid overpayments.
articles.author: Financial Support Team, Age UK

articles.title: Power of Attorney: What Carers Need to Know
articles.summary: Essential information about setting up and managing Lasting Power of Attorney for elderly relatives in the UK.
articles.content:
Power of Attorney: What Carers Need to Know

Power of Attorney is a legal document that allows someone to make decisions on another person's behalf. Understanding this legal arrangement is crucial for many carers.

Types of Power of Attorney

In England and Wales, there are two types of Lasting Power of Attorney (LPA):

  1. Health and Welfare LPA - Covers decisions about healthcare, living arrangements, and day-to-day care
  2. Property and Financial Affairs LPA - Covers managing bank accounts, paying bills, and selling property

Scotland and Northern Ireland have different systems with similar purposes.

When to Set Up an LPA

The best time to set up an LPA is when the person still has mental capacity. An LPA cannot be set up once someone has lost capacity to make their own decisions.

The Application Process

To set up an LPA, you need to:

  1. Get the LPA forms from the Office of the Public Guardian or complete them online
  2. Have the person (donor) choose their attorney(s) and specify how decisions should be made
  3. Get a 'certificate provider' to confirm the donor understands the LPA and isn't being pressured
  4. Register the LPA with the Office of the Public Guardian (this takes 8-10 weeks and costs £82 per LPA)

Your Responsibilities as an Attorney

As an attorney, you must:

  • Always act in the best interests of the donor
  • Consider the donor's wishes and feelings
  • Help them make their own decisions where possible
  • Keep the donor's money separate from your own
  • Keep accurate records of decisions and transactions

What If There's No LPA?

If someone loses capacity without an LPA in place, you may need to apply to the Court of Protection to become a deputy, which is more complex and expensive.

Getting Help

Consider seeking advice from a solicitor, especially for complex situations. Organizations like Age UK and Citizens Advice can also provide guidance.
articles.author: Sarah Williams, Legal Advisor

articles.title: Managing Medication for Elderly People
articles.summary: Practical advice for carers on managing complex medication regimes safely and effectively.
articles.content:
Managing Medication for Elderly People

Many elderly people take multiple medications, which can be challenging to manage. This guide offers practical tips for carers to ensure medications are taken safely and correctly.

Understanding the Medication Regimen

Ask the GP or pharmacist for a comprehensive medication review and a clear explanation of:

  • What each medication is for
  • How and when each should be taken
  • Potential side effects to watch for
  • Which medications interact with each other or with certain foods
  • Which symptoms need urgent medical attention

Organizing Medications

Consider using:

  • Pill organizers (dosette boxes) - These compartmentalized boxes help sort medications by day and time
  • Medication reminder apps - Smartphone applications that send alerts when it's time to take medication
  • Pharmacy blister packs - Pre-packaged doses prepared by pharmacists
  • Medicine cabinets - Keep all medications in one secure, appropriate place

Administering Medications

When helping someone take their medication:

  • Ensure they are sitting upright to prevent choking
  • Offer plenty of water (unless contraindicated)
  • Never crush tablets or open capsules without checking with a pharmacist first
  • For eye drops or inhalers, check the correct technique with a healthcare professional

Keeping Track

Maintain a medication log recording:

  • When medications were taken
  • Any missed doses
  • Observed side effects
  • When prescriptions need renewing

Managing Prescriptions

Consider:

  • Setting up repeat prescriptions with your GP
  • Using online ordering systems if available
  • Arranging prescription delivery services
  • Keeping an emergency supply of essential medications

Medication Reviews

Request regular medication reviews with the GP to:

  • Check if all medications are still necessary
  • Adjust doses if needed
  • Monitor for cumulative side effects of multiple medications
  • Consider alternatives if certain medications are causing problems
articles.author: Dr. Helen Morris, Geriatric Pharmacist

articles.title: Nutrition in Later Life: A Guide for Carers
articles.summary: How to ensure elderly people receive proper nutrition even when appetites decline and eating habits change.
articles.content:
Nutrition in Later Life: A Guide for Carers

Good nutrition is vital for maintaining health, independence, and quality of life in older age. However, many factors can make eating well more challenging for elderly people.

Understanding Changed Nutritional Needs

As people age:

  • Calorie requirements may decrease due to reduced activity, but nutrient needs remain similar or increase
  • Protein becomes more important for maintaining muscle mass
  • Vitamin D, calcium, and B vitamins may need supplementation
  • Hydration becomes critically important but thirst sensation often decreases

Common Challenges with Eating

Be aware of factors that might affect eating:

  • Physical changes - Reduced sense of taste/smell, dental problems, swallowing difficulties
  • Health conditions - Dementia, depression, chronic illness affecting appetite
  • Medications - Side effects affecting taste or causing nausea
  • Practical issues - Difficulty preparing food or shopping, eating alone

Strategies for Better Nutrition

Practical approaches include:

  • Nutrient-dense meals - Focus on quality not quantity, with protein at each meal
  • Regular small meals - Five to six smaller meals may be more manageable than three large ones
  • Fortified foods - Add extra nutrition with milk powder, cheese, ground nuts, or olive oil
  • Texture modifications - Soft or pureed foods for those with chewing/swallowing difficulties
  • Food presentation - Attractive, colorful meals served on contrasting plates
  • Social eating - Make mealtimes social occasions where possible

Hydration Tips

Ensure adequate fluid intake by:

  • Offering a variety of drinks throughout the day
  • Providing a visual reminder like a water jug
  • Offering fluid-rich foods like soup, yogurt, and fruit
  • Watching for dehydration signs like dark urine or confusion

When to Seek Help

Consult a healthcare professional if you notice:

  • Unintentional weight loss
  • Loss of appetite for more than a few days
  • Swallowing difficulties or choking
  • Recurrent chest infections (might indicate aspiration)

Ask for a referral to a dietitian if nutrition is an ongoing concern.
articles.author: Emily Parker, Registered Dietitian

articles.title: Dementia: Communication Strategies for Carers
articles.summary: Effective techniques for communicating with people living with dementia to reduce frustration and maintain meaningful connections.
articles.content:
Dementia: Communication Strategies for Carers

Communication difficulties are common in dementia and can be frustrating for both the person with dementia and their carers. These strategies can help maintain meaningful connections.

Understanding Communication Changes

People with dementia may experience:

  • Difficulty finding the right words
  • Repeating questions or stories
  • Losing track of conversations
  • Problems understanding complex instructions
  • Reverting to a first language if English was learned later in life
  • Increased reliance on non-verbal communication

Creating the Right Environment

For better communication:

  • Reduce background noise and distractions
  • Ensure good lighting so your face is visible
  • Position yourself at eye level, not standing over them
  • Maintain an appropriate distance - close enough to hear but respecting personal space
  • Turn off TVs or radios during important conversations

Verbal Communication Tips

When speaking:

  • Use simple, direct sentences with familiar words
  • Speak slowly and clearly, but with a normal adult tone (not childish)
  • Ask one question at a time and wait for a response
  • Offer simple choices rather than open-ended questions
  • Avoid testing questions like 'Do you remember..?'
  • Use names and pronouns consistently (avoid 'he' or 'she')

Non-Verbal Communication

Remember that:

  • Your body language, facial expressions, and tone communicate more than words
  • Maintain eye contact and smile genuinely
  • Use gentle touch appropriately to reassure and communicate care
  • Demonstrate actions while explaining them
  • Be aware of signs of frustration or distress

Responding to Repetition

When questions or stories are repeated:

  • Answer as if hearing for the first time
  • Try redirecting to a related topic
  • Consider if there's an unmet need behind the repetition
  • Use written reminders or familiar objects for orientation

Managing Difficult Moments

If communication becomes difficult:

  • Stay calm and patient
  • Validate feelings even if the content doesn't make sense
  • Try changing the subject or environment
  • Take a short break if you're becoming frustrated
  • Remember it's the disease causing the difficulty, not the person
articles.author: Dr. Robert Chen, Dementia Specialist

articles.title: Carer Burnout: Recognizing the Signs and Finding Help
articles.summary: How to identify symptoms of carer burnout and practical strategies for self-care and seeking support.
articles.content:
Carer Burnout: Recognizing the Signs and Finding Help

Caring for an elderly loved one can be rewarding but also physically and emotionally demanding. Recognizing and addressing carer burnout is essential for your wellbeing and your ability to provide good care.

Understanding Carer Burnout

Carer burnout is a state of physical, emotional, and mental exhaustion that occurs when carers don't get the help they need or try to do more than they are able—physically or financially.

Warning Signs

You might be experiencing burnout if you notice:

  • Physical symptoms - Constant fatigue, getting sick more often, changes in appetite or sleep
  • Emotional changes - Increased irritability, anxiety, depression, or feeling helpless
  • Behavioral signs - Withdrawing from friends, neglecting your own needs, using alcohol or sleep medications to cope
  • Cognitive issues - Trouble concentrating, increasingly forgetful
  • Relationship strain - Feeling resentful toward the person you're caring for, conflicts with family members

Prevention Strategies

To prevent burnout:

Set realistic expectations

  • Accept that you can't do everything perfectly
  • Prioritize essential tasks and let go of less important ones
  • Set boundaries on what you can and cannot do

Ask for and accept help

  • Make a list of specific tasks others could help with
  • Don't wait until you're overwhelmed to ask for support
  • Consider both informal (family/friends) and formal (services) help

Take care of your own health

  • Schedule regular health check-ups
  • Prioritize sleep and proper nutrition
  • Find ways to incorporate physical activity

Stay connected

  • Join a carers' support group (in-person or online)
  • Maintain relationships outside your caring role
  • Share your feelings with trusted friends or a therapist

Finding Respite

Regular breaks are essential. Consider:

  • Arranging for a family member to take over regularly
  • Using respite care services through your local council
  • Day centres where the person you care for can spend time
  • Befriending services or sitting services

Financial Support

Caring can create financial strain. Look into:

  • Carer's Allowance and other benefits
  • Local authority support following a carer's assessment
  • Charitable grants for carers

When to Seek Professional Help

If you're experiencing persistent low mood, anxiety, or feeling unable to cope, speak to your GP. They can refer you to appropriate mental health support or counseling.
articles.author: Jennifer Adams, Mental Health Counselor

articles.title: Accessing NHS Continuing Healthcare Funding
articles.summary: A step-by-step guide to navigating the NHS Continuing Healthcare assessment process for elderly people with significant health needs.
articles.content:
Accessing NHS Continuing Healthcare Funding

NHS Continuing Healthcare (CHC) is a package of care fully funded by the NHS for people with significant health needs. Understanding this complex process can make a substantial difference to care options and finances.

What is NHS Continuing Healthcare?

CHC is care provided and fully funded by the NHS for individuals whose primary need is health-related. It can cover care at home or in a care home and is not means-tested, unlike local authority social care.

Who Might Be Eligible?

Eligibility is based on having a 'primary health need' rather than specific conditions. Assessment considers the:

  • Nature of needs (the characteristics and type of care required)
  • Complexity (how different needs interact)
  • Intensity (the severity and required level of care)
  • Unpredictability (how difficult needs are to manage or anticipate)

Those nearing end of life may be eligible for a Fast Track assessment.

The Assessment Process

Step 1: Initial Checklist

A health or social care professional completes an initial screening tool (the Checklist). If this indicates possible eligibility, they'll refer for a full assessment.

Step 2: Full Assessment

A multidisciplinary team (MDT) of health and social care professionals conducts a detailed assessment using the Decision Support Tool (DST). This evaluates needs across 12 care domains including:

  • Breathing
  • Nutrition
  • Continence
  • Mobility
  • Cognition
  • Behavior
  • Medication management
  • And others

Step 3: Decision

The MDT makes a recommendation to the Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG), who makes the final decision. You should be informed in writing with detailed reasons.

If Funding is Approved

The NHS will work with you to arrange a care package that meets assessed needs. This might be in a care home or at home. Regular reviews will assess if needs have changed.

If Funding is Declined

You have the right to appeal through:

  1. An informal resolution meeting with the CCG
  2. A formal local appeal process
  3. If still unresolved, requesting an independent review from NHS England
  4. As a final step, approaching the Parliamentary and Health Service Ombudsman

Tips for the Process

  • Keep detailed records of health needs and care provided
  • Gather evidence from all healthcare professionals involved
  • Attend the assessment meeting and consider bringing an advocate
  • Understand the eligibility criteria before the assessment
  • Consider getting expert advice from organizations like Beacon CHC
articles.author: Michael Thompson, Healthcare Funding Specialist

articles.title: Fall Prevention at Home
articles.summary: Practical home modification and lifestyle changes to reduce fall risks for elderly people.
articles.content:
Fall Prevention at Home

Falls are a leading cause of injury for older adults, but many falls can be prevented with simple home modifications and lifestyle changes.

Understanding Fall Risks

Common risk factors include:

  • Previous falls or fear of falling
  • Muscle weakness, especially in the legs
  • Balance or gait problems
  • Poor vision
  • Certain medications that cause dizziness or affect balance
  • Chronic conditions like arthritis, stroke, or Parkinson's
  • Environmental hazards at home

Essential Home Modifications

Throughout the home:

  • Ensure good lighting, especially on stairs and in hallways
  • Install handrails on both sides of all stairs
  • Secure all loose rugs with non-slip backing or remove them entirely
  • Keep walkways clear of clutter, trailing cables, and low furniture
  • Consider contrasting colors for floor edges and steps to improve visibility

In the bathroom:

  • Install grab bars near the toilet and in the shower/bath
  • Use non-slip mats in the shower and bath
  • Consider a shower seat and handheld shower head
  • Raise the toilet seat height if needed

In the bedroom:

  • Ensure the bed is at an appropriate height (knees should bend at about 90 degrees when sitting)
  • Place a lamp within easy reach of the bed
  • Consider motion-activated night lights
  • Keep walking aids within reach

In the kitchen:

  • Rearrange frequently used items to avoid reaching or bending
  • Use a reaching aid for high or low items
  • Clean spills immediately
  • Consider perching stools for tasks that take time

Personal Strategies

  • Encourage strength and balance exercises - Programs like Tai Chi are particularly effective
  • Arrange regular vision and hearing checks - Poor vision and hearing can affect balance
  • Review medications - Ask the GP to review all medications that might affect balance
  • Choose appropriate footwear - Well-fitting shoes with non-slip soles
  • Use mobility aids correctly - Ensure walking frames or sticks are the right height and used properly
  • Address urinary urgency - Rushing to the bathroom is a common fall trigger

Technology and Equipment

  • Personal alarms or emergency response systems
  • Hip protectors for those at high risk of fractures
  • Motion-activated lighting
  • Smart home systems to control lighting and heating

Creating a Fall Response Plan

Discuss what to do if a fall occurs:

  • How to get up safely if able
  • How to call for help (keeping a mobile phone accessible)
  • What to do while waiting for help (staying warm, changing position gradually)

Consider practicing safe ways to get up from the floor if appropriate.
articles.author: Olivia Martinez, Occupational Therapist

articles.title: Understanding and Responding to Challenging Behaviors in Dementia
articles.summary: Guidance on managing common behavioral symptoms in dementia, including aggression, wandering, and repetitive behaviors.
articles.content:
Understanding and Responding to Challenging Behaviors in Dementia

Behavioral symptoms are common in dementia and often more difficult to manage than memory problems. Understanding the causes and appropriate responses can improve quality of life for both the person with dementia and their carers.

Why Challenging Behaviors Occur

Behaviors are often a form of communication when verbal abilities decline. Common triggers include:

  • Physical discomfort - Pain, illness, medication side effects, hunger, thirst, or need for the toilet
  • Environmental factors - Overstimulation, unfamiliar surroundings, poor lighting, or too much noise
  • Emotional distress - Confusion, fear, depression, or feeling lost
  • Unmet needs - Boredom, loneliness, or need for activity
  • Communication difficulties - Frustration at not being understood

Common Behaviors and Response Strategies

Agitation and Aggression

Strategies include:

  • Stay calm and speak in a reassuring, non-confrontational manner
  • Give the person space if safe to do so
  • Look for physical causes (pain, discomfort)
  • Simplify the environment and reduce demands
  • Try distraction with a favorite activity or topic

Wandering

Approaches include:

  • Ensure regular exercise and activity to reduce restlessness
  • Create safe walking paths inside and in secure outdoor areas
  • Use door alarms or monitoring technology
  • Consider identification bracelets or tracking devices
  • Establish regular routines to minimize confusion

Repetitive Questions or Actions

Try these techniques:

  • Look for the feeling behind the repetition - is it anxiety, boredom?
  • Answer simply each time or try gentle redirection
  • Provide reassurance and security
  • Try written reminders or memory aids for some people
  • Engage in meaningful activities that use preserved skills

Sundowning (Increased Confusion in Late Afternoon/Evening)

Helpful approaches:

  • Maintain a predictable routine
  • Limit caffeine and sugar later in the day
  • Reduce stimulation in the evening (quieter activities, softer lighting)
  • Address any sleep problems
  • Consider whether the person is tired or hungry

General Principles

  • Person-centered approach - See the person, not just the behavior
  • Look for patterns - Keep a log to identify triggers and successful strategies
  • Try non-drug approaches first - Medication should rarely be the first option
  • Consistent approach - Ensure all carers respond similarly
  • Adapt the environment - Create a calm, structured, familiar setting

When to Seek Help

Consult healthcare professionals if:

  • Behaviors pose a risk to the person or others
  • They cause significant distress
  • They occur suddenly or represent a marked change
  • You feel unable to cope despite trying various approaches

Specialist dementia nurses, mental health teams, or dementia support organizations can provide advice and support.
articles.author: Dr. Amina Patel, Dementia Specialist

articles.title: Respite Care Options in the UK
articles.summary: A guide to different types of respite care services, how to arrange them, and potential funding sources.
articles.content:
Respite Care Options in the UK

Respite care provides temporary relief for carers, allowing them to take a break while ensuring their loved one receives appropriate care. Regular respite is essential for sustainable caring and benefits both carers and those they care for.

Types of Respite Care

In-home respite

Care professionals come to the home, which can include:

  • Sitting services - Someone stays with the person for a few hours while you go out
  • Domiciliary care - Help with personal care, medications, or meals
  • Live-in care - A professional carer lives in the home temporarily
  • Night attendants - Allow you to get uninterrupted sleep

Out-of-home respite

Options include:

  • Day centres - Provide activities, social interaction, and care during daytime hours
  • Residential short breaks - Temporary stays in care homes (typically 1-2 weeks)
  • Respite holidays - Specialized holidays with care support
  • Shared Lives schemes - Stays with an approved family who provide support

Finding and Arranging Respite

Sources of respite care include:

  • Local authority social services - Request a carer's assessment to determine eligibility for funded respite
  • NHS respite - May be available for those with significant health needs
  • Private arrangements - Directly hiring care agencies or booking care home stays
  • Charitable organizations - Some provide free or subsidized respite services

To arrange respite:

  1. Contact your local council's adult social services department for a carer's assessment
  2. Speak with your GP or district nurse about health-related respite needs
  3. Research local care agencies and care homes that offer respite
  4. Contact condition-specific charities (e.g., Alzheimer's Society, Parkinson's UK)

Funding Respite Care

Potential funding sources include:

  • Local authority funding - Following carer and needs assessments
  • NHS funding - For those eligible for Continuing Healthcare
  • Charitable grants - Organizations like the Carers Trust offer grants for breaks
  • Self-funding - Using direct payments or your own resources

Costs vary widely depending on the type of respite and location. In-home care typically ranges from £15-30 per hour, while care home respite can cost £600-1,500 per week.

Preparing for Respite

To make respite successful:

  • Plan well in advance, especially for residential respite
  • Prepare detailed information about routines, preferences, and care needs
  • Visit facilities beforehand if possible
  • Start with shorter periods of respite before longer breaks
  • Explain the temporary nature of the arrangement to your loved one
  • Stay positive but acknowledge that adjustment may take time

Overcoming Guilt

Many carers feel guilty about using respite. Remember that:

  • Taking breaks makes you a better, more sustainable carer
  • The person you care for may benefit from new interactions and environments
  • Your health and wellbeing matter too
  • Respite is a normal, recommended part of caring, not a failure
articles.author: Laura Bailey, Carers Support Coordinator

articles.title: Creating an End-of-Life Care Plan
articles.summary: How to approach sensitive conversations about end-of-life wishes and document them effectively.
articles.content:
Creating an End-of-Life Care Plan

Discussing and documenting end-of-life wishes can feel difficult but provides invaluable guidance during challenging times. A clear plan ensures care aligns with personal values and preferences.

Starting the Conversation

Tips for initiating difficult discussions:

  • Choose a quiet, comfortable setting without distractions
  • Use natural openings such as relevant news stories or family events
  • Start with broader values questions before specific medical decisions
  • Listen more than you speak, allowing time for reflection
  • Respect reluctance but gently try again another time
  • Involve other family members as appropriate

Key Elements to Discuss

Medical Preferences

  • Preferred place of care (home, hospital, hospice, care home)
  • Views on life-sustaining treatments (CPR, ventilation, feeding tubes)
  • Pain management and symptom control priorities
  • Acceptable quality of life considerations
  • Religious or cultural practices important during illness or after death

Personal Matters

  • Important relationships and who should be present if possible
  • Unresolved personal matters or wishes
  • How they would like to be remembered
  • Funeral or memorial preferences
  • Messages for loved ones

Documenting Wishes Formally

Important documents to consider:

Advance Statement

A general document outlining values, preferences, and important information that isn't legally binding but guides decision-making.

Advance Decision to Refuse Treatment (ADRT)

A legally binding document refusing specific treatments in specific circumstances. Must be:

  • Made by someone with capacity
  • Written, signed, and witnessed if refusing life-sustaining treatment
  • Specific about which treatments are refused and in what circumstances

Lasting Power of Attorney for Health and Welfare

Legally appoints someone to make healthcare decisions if capacity is lost. The appointed person must follow any valid ADRT.

DNACPR (Do Not Attempt Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation)

A medical decision, documented on a specific form, usually completed with healthcare professionals.

Practical Storage and Access

  • Keep original documents in a secure but accessible location
  • Share copies with the GP, appointed attorneys, and close family
  • Consider registering advance decisions with your medical records
  • Some people carry a card or wear medical alert jewelry indicating advance decisions
  • Review documents periodically as wishes may change

Involving Healthcare Professionals

Healthcare professionals can:

  • Provide medical information to inform decisions
  • Help complete documentation correctly
  • Record wishes in medical records
  • Initiate specialized care planning like Recommended Summary Plan for Emergency Care and Treatment (ReSPECT)
  • Connect you with appropriate services like palliative care teams

Additional Support

Organizations that can help with advance care planning include:

  • Compassion in Dying
  • Age UK
  • Hospice UK
  • Marie Curie
  • Macmillan Cancer Support
articles.author: Caroline Wilson, Palliative Care Nurse
